content: How can I help you today?

I’ve been having a really hard time sleeping lately, and it’s starting to stress me out even more. My partner encouraged me to try talking with someone, but honestly, I’m not sure if this will help. I just feel stuck.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like your sleep struggles have been weighing heavily on you, and the stress might be making things harder. It also seems like you care enough about addressing this that you're willing to explore options, even if you're unsure about them right now. Would you like to talk more about what's been going on or how this has been affecting you?

Yeah... it's just that I can't seem to shut my brain off at night. There's so much on my mind with work. I'm scared of losing my job and not being able to take care of my family, and these thoughts just loop over and over. I end up staring at my phone to distract myself, but I know that's just making it worse.

You're carrying a lot right now, with work worries and the responsibility of providing for your family. It makes sense that those thoughts would keep looping—you care deeply about them, and they're hard to set aside. Reaching for your phone sounds like you're trying to find some relief in the moment, even though you know it might not be helping. It must feel exhausting to juggle all of that at night. How do you feel about how this has been impacting you during the day?

Honestly, it’s draining. I feel like I’m running on fumes most of the time. I’m more irritable, and I don’t have much energy to be present for my kids or focus at work. It’s like this vicious cycle, and I don’t know how to break out of it.

It sounds extremely challenging to feel so drained and stuck in a cycle that’s affecting your energy, mood, and the way you’re showing up for your kids and work. It seems like you really want things to change so you can be more present and feel more in control, but it feels overwhelming to even know where to start. What do you think might help you begin to ease some of this strain, if anything?

I don’t know. Part of me thinks if I could just figure out how to shut off my brain at night, it might help everything else. But that’s easier said than done, and I haven’t been able to stop the thoughts. It’s hard to even imagine what would help right now.

It’s understandable to feel unsure when it seems like your thoughts are running on autopilot each night. You’re expressing that there’s a part of you that believes finding a way to calm your mind could make a big difference, even though the path to getting there feels unclear. It shows how much you’re hoping for relief. What do you think has been getting in the way of exploring solutions, or trying something new?

I think part of it is that I’m just so used to dealing with things on my own, and I’m not sure where to even begin. Plus, trying something new feels risky—it’s like, what if it doesn’t work and I’m back at square one? That thought makes me hesitant to even try.

It makes sense that you’d feel uncertain about trying something new, especially when you’ve been managing everything on your own for so long. That hesitation around risking disappointment—putting effort into something but fearing it might not help—sounds like it’s been keeping you from taking that first step. At the same time, it seems like you’re open to the idea of change, even if there’s fear attached to it. What would it mean for you if something did work?

If something did work, I think it would mean finally feeling a little more in control. Being able to sleep better and quiet my mind would help me show up for my family the way I want to, and maybe even feel less on edge at work. It’s just scary to think about how far that feels from where I’m at right now.

It sounds like being able to sleep better and quiet your mind is something you really value—it could give you the energy and focus to show up for your family and feel more calm and capable at work. The idea of that change feels important to you, even though it seems far off and a little scary right now. What do you think about taking small steps toward that goal, rather than needing to tackle everything all at once?

I guess small steps could feel more manageable than trying to fix everything at once, but I’m not even sure what those steps would look like. It’s just hard to know where to start, and I don’t want to do something that ends up feeling like a waste of time.

Taking small steps can be less overwhelming, but uncertainty about where to start—especially when you want to make sure your time and energy aren’t wasted—sounds like it's been holding you back. You’re clearly thoughtful about how you approach this, and that’s an important strength. Would it help if we explored ideas together to find steps that might feel meaningful and worth trying?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
